s.text: Trying, but not succeeding, not even with one of my brightest students.
Trying, but not succeeding, not even with one of my brightest students.
Reasonable people have disagreed with the particulars I recommend.
When the concern about kids and "porn" became pressing, many said a perfect solution would be code that helped filter content on the Net.
There's this really awful experience that some teachers know--not great teachers, but ordinary teachers, or at least teachers who have not taught well.

The argument is about the commons, not the ends; it is about the control that is enabled for those in the Internet we know now; and it is about the control that gets enabled because of the emergence of one kind of architecture of identity.

You give your name to one site, but choose not to give your name to another, yet unbeknownst to you, the sites are allied, and using a common cookie identification, they can share what you didn't want shared.
And obviously before reviewing a book, a scholar such as Richard would have read it.
But in my book, I told the story about an increasingly "certificate-rich" Internet--meaning an Internet where people more and more frequently carried ("voluntarily") digital IDs.
